page.title: 07Quarries in the Colne Valley
page.content: Stone quarrying was a very important industry during the growth of textiles, the local sandstone being excellent for building the mills and houses. Most of the quarries are now disused, except for Johnsons Quarry at Crosland Hill, which employs 120 men. Large quantities of sand and aggregate are produced for the building industry by a large stone crushing plant. The larger pieces of York sandstone,some weighing 40 tonnes are sawn into smaller slabs and pieces for building orders. Huge saws with diamond tipped blades are used for trimming and shaping the stone. It is possible to make pieces of almost any shape on the machines in the stone- masons sheds. The stone from this quarry is popular with builders and architects.
